results.title: Protein synthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Biology students will quickly grasp the importance of proteins as the basic building blocks of life and the fundamental role that protein synthesis plays in all living things from these six 10 minute episodes. Each episode explores one aspect of the process, from the manufacture of DNA to the roles of the messenger and transfer RNA. Computer animation provides clear demonstrations that make this complex subject easily understood. The programs include: 1. “Protein: the stuff of life” 2. “DNA: the molecule of heredity messenger” 3. “DNA: Replication: the repeating formula” 4. “RNA Synthesis: the genetic messenger maker” 5. Transfer RNA: the genetic” 6. “Ribosomal RNA: the protein.

results.title: Photosynthesis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Exciting 3-D computer animations show the dynamic process of photosynthesis at the molecular level. Starting with the historic discoveries of Joseph Priestley, Jan Ingenhousz and Jean Senebier, these six 10 minute episodes examine the absorption of light by plants, and follows the energy pathways to the production of carbohydrates and other organic materials. Programs also develop the Calvin cycle, as it functions in Carbon 3 and Carbon 4 plants, and the remarkable fluid transport system that delivers water and nutrients throughout the plant structure. The programs include: 1. “Seeing the light” 2. “Absorbing the light” 3. “The Light reaction” 4. “The Dark reaction” 5. “C3 and C4 plants” 6. “The Fluid transport system.”

results.title: Homeostasis
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and Television Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
Homeostasis explores the internal systems of balance and regulation in animals. With the assistance of computer animation, sequences illustrate how the body deals with stress and copes with changing conditions such as high and low temperatures, and how the shortage or excess of fluids is adjusted and regulated. Six 10 minute episodes present students at secondary and post secondary levels with a comprehensible definition of homeostasis with examples of how it works, and how this on-going balancing of internal conditions to external changes and stimuli is triggered and monitored. Includes: 1. “Coping with change”, 2. “The Sea within”, 3. “Osmoregulation”, 4. ” The Feedback cycle”, 5. “Biochemical balances”, 6. “Hormonal control.”

results.title: Cellular respiration
results.creator_credit: David Chamberlain, Ontario Educational Communications Authority and TV Ontario
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Concepts in science: biology”.
These six 10 minute programs use computer animation to illustrate facets of biological respiration. They begin with a historical perspective, and gradually proceed into modern research and theories, examining enzymes, coensymes, phosphorylation, biosynthesis, glycolysis and the citric acid cycle. The programs include: 1. Metabolism 4. Fermentation 2. Glycolysis 5. Krebs cycle 3. Redox reactions in glycolysis 6. Energy flow in respiration

results.title: Networks in Project Management (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Computing and Computers”.
Computers can be used to help manage large projects. Shows how critical path analysis involving the use of a data structure network is used by a studio design team in the BBC

results.title: Secular soul. Part 3. Atheists [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. The final episode looks at four prominent Australian atheists, how they reached their decision to become an atheist and how they live their lives in the absence of religion. Interviewees include: Peter Singer, the child of Jewish refugees and a philosopher and ethicist renowned for his controversial view on euthanasia and animal rights; geology professor Ian Plimer who grew up in Sydney in the 1940s and 50s and took a Christian fundamentalist to court on the grounds that they were peddling misleading information; Diana Warnock, ex West Australian Labor politician and now a community activist; and Dick Gross, former mayor of St Kilda and founder of the Jewish Saturday school, a secular, humanist alternative which involves culture and ethnicity minus the religion. The four speak of the importance of ritual, the possibility of ethics derived from reason as opposed to religion, life after death, and whether religion is increased or decreased in the face of adversity. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Secular soul. Part 1. Spiritual market place [Widescreen]
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
Presented by Geraldine Doogue, this three part series looks at the changing patterns of belief in Australia. Episode one examines the decline in attendance at traditional churches and the incidence of “spiritual shopping” whereby people are creating their own personal style of religion. In looking at the decline in church attendance since the 1960s and the melding of the experiential and the emotional, Doogue speaks to university lecturers Carole Cusack and David Tacey, Uniting Church Minister and director of the Christian Research Association Philip Hughes, and Anglican priest and sociologist Gary Bouma. The program also looks at the growth in Pentecostal churches, spending time at the Mount Annan Christian Life Centre, speaking to Andrew and Adrian Gray about their work. Youths also describe their experiences during an empowering conference. Features vox pops at Sydney nightclub and Acland Street, St Kilda. Part of the television show, “Compass”.

results.title: Encounters with Islam [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Roger Bayley and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Compass (Television program)”.
This program discusses the aftermath of September 11 and its impact on Australian Muslims who represent just over 1% of the Australian population. Whilst focusing on some of the negative aspects including vilification, violence and antagonism towards women by non-Muslims, vandal attacks on mosques and a media which seemed to be more intent on dividing the community rather than uniting it, “Encounters with Islam” also seeks to reveal a more positive view. Through interviews with various leaders of the Islamic community, academics, young people and non-Muslims, it is apparent that a re-evaluation is taking place amongst the Muslims and a recognition that their world of Islam needs to be demystified and the Australian population informed. The link of crime and acts of terrorism with Muslims stems from not only the tragedy of September 11, but also preceding incidents in Sydney of gang rapes and drug related crimes allegedly by men of Muslim backgrounds. Misunderstanding and prejudice are trying to be counteracted through dialogue and discussion between the different faiths, support, understanding and a “fair go” by the non-Muslim Australian community and a better educated and more sensitive media. Presented by Geraldine Doogue.
